title: Year-End Celebration — Menu Planning
description: The child plans a special year-end celebration meal for the family. They choose dishes, create a menu, and write a shopping list. This synthesizes all practical life skills: planning, writing, food knowledge, and hosting.
instructions:
1. 'We are planning a CELEBRATION FEAST for the end of your kindergarten year! You are the head chef and planner.'
2. Discuss: 'What special food should we make? Think about meals you have helped prepare this year.'
3. Guide the child to plan a balanced menu: appetizer or snack, main dish, side dish, dessert, drinks.
4. Write the menu on decorative paper: 'Year-End Celebration Menu — Chef [child's name].'
5. Create a shopping list together, checking the pantry for what you already have.
6. Organize the list by store sections: produce, dairy, bakery, etc.
7. 'Tomorrow we will shop and start cooking!'
materials_needed: Cookbooks or recipe cards from the year (optional)

slides.heading: Celebration Feast
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at this fun title! We're going to plan a super special "Celebration Feast" for our family. It's like planning a big party with all our favorite yummy foods!

items: Paper for menu and shopping list
slides.setup_instructions: Set up at the kitchen table. Have past recipe cards or cookbooks available for inspiration.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at all these wonderful things we get to use! We have pretty paper to make our special menu, a pencil to write with, and colorful pencils to make it look amazing. We also have some cookbooks, which are like treasure maps for yummy recipes!

slides.text: 'You have cooked so many things this year! Now YOU get to plan a whole celebration meal for our family. What should we make?'
slides.mascot_explanation: You've been such a great helper in the kitchen all year, and now it's YOUR turn to be the head chef! We get to decide everything we want to eat for our big celebration meal. What yummy foods do you think our family would love?

slides.text: 'A good meal has different parts: something to start, a main dish, a side dish, and a dessert. What sounds delicious for each?'
slides.mascot_explanation: A super yummy meal has lots of different parts, like a puzzle! We need something fun to start, like a yummy snack, then the main food, something yummy to go with it, and of course, a sweet dessert! What sounds extra delicious for each part?

slides.text: 'Let's write your menu on this special paper. Write each dish and decorate it beautifully — this will be on the table at our feast!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we get to write down all the yummy food we picked for our feast on this special paper. We'll write down each dish and then make it look so pretty with colors! This menu will be like a special sign for our amazing meal.

slides.text: 'Now the shopping list! What ingredients do we need? Let's check what we already have at home first.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, Chef! Now we need to make a list of all the things we need to buy to make our yummy food. We'll look in our kitchen first to see what yummy things we already have, and then we'll write down what else we need.

slides.prompt: Write and decorate your celebration menu. Then create a shopping list organized by store sections: fruits and vegetables, dairy, bread, and other.
slides.mascot_explanation: It's time to get creative! Let's write down all the yummy foods for our menu and draw beautiful pictures to make it extra special. Then, we'll make our shopping list and put the food in groups, like all the fruits and veggies together.

slides.text: 'You planned a whole meal from start to finish! A real chef plans, shops, and then cooks. We will do the shopping and cooking next!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child plan a balanced multi-course meal and create an organized shopping list?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did it! You planned a whole amazing meal all by yourself, just like a real super chef! You thought about all the yummy foods and made a perfect shopping list. Tomorrow, we'll go get the food and start cooking our feast!

parent_notes: Menu planning is an executive function masterclass: it requires sequencing (what to cook first), categorization (food groups, store sections), literacy (writing the menu and list), math (quantities), and social awareness (what will the family enjoy). The child has done individual cooking activities all year; now they synthesize it into a full meal plan. Let them make real choices — if they want pancakes for the main course, celebrate their independence! Gently guide toward balance ('What vegetable could we add?') without overriding. The decorated menu becomes a table centerpiece for the celebration. This is the capstone practical life activity because it encompasses planning, literacy, math, social awareness, and cooking.

title: Thank You Notes — Expressing Gratitude in Writing
description: The child writes thank you notes to people who supported their learning this year — family members, friends, librarians, or anyone who helped them grow. This combines writing skills with grace and courtesy.
instructions:
1. 'When someone helps us, we say thank you. But a written thank you is extra special because they can keep it forever!'
2. Brainstorm together: 'Who helped you learn this year? Who are you grateful for?'
3. Model a thank you note format: Dear ___, Thank you for ___. My favorite memory is ___. Love, [name].
4. Child writes 2-3 thank you notes.
5. Address envelopes if mailing, or fold for hand delivery.
6. Decorate notes with small drawings.
7. 'These will make people so happy!'

slides.heading: Thank You Notes
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at this! It says "Thank You Notes." We're going to learn how to write special notes to tell people how thankful we are for them. It's like giving them a warm hug with words!

slides.setup_instructions: Fold paper into card-sized notes or use pre-made cards. Have a list of potential recipients ready.
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's get our special writing stuff ready! We have paper or cards to write on, a pencil to write our words, and colorful pencils to make them pretty. We also have envelopes to put them in, and maybe even stamps to send them far away! Ask a grown-up to help you find all these things.

slides.text: 'One of the most beautiful things we can do with our writing is say THANK YOU. A letter someone can hold is even more special than just words.'
slides.mascot_explanation: You know how sometimes people help us, like when someone reads you a story or helps you build a tower? We can say "thank you" out loud, but writing a note is super special because they can keep it forever and ever! It’s a way to show them we really, really appreciate them.

slides.text: 'Who are you thankful for this year? Who helped you, taught you, or made you smile? Let's make a list.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, let's think about all the wonderful people who helped you learn and grow this year. Who made you feel happy? Who taught you something new? Let's whisper their names to our grown-up so we can remember them for our special notes.

slides.text: 'Here is how to write a thank you note: Dear [name], Thank you for [what they did]. My favorite memory with you is [memory]. Love, [your name].'
slides.mascot_explanation: This is how we write our thank you note! We start with "Dear," and then the person's name. Next, we say "Thank you for..." and tell them what they did that was so nice. Then, we can say our "favorite memory" with them. And we finish with "Love" and your name!

slides.text: 'Write your first note. Sound out any tricky words. Then decorate it with a small drawing that matches your message.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's your turn to write! Take your time and sound out the words, or ask your grown-up for help. After you write your thank you, you can draw a little picture to make it even more special. Maybe a drawing of what you're thanking them for!

slides.prompt: Write 2 or 3 thank you notes to people who helped you this year. Decorate each one. Address the envelopes if you are mailing them!
slides.mascot_explanation: It's time to make some happy hearts! Let's write two or three thank you notes to the people we thought of. You can draw a picture on each one, and if you're sending them in the mail, we'll put them in their envelopes and maybe even add a stamp!

slides.text: 'These notes will bring so much joy! When we take time to say thank you, we make the world a kinder place. And YOU wrote them all by yourself!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child compose a thank you note with a greeting, specific message of gratitude, and closing?
slides.mascot_explanation: Yay, you did it! Look at all the beautiful thank you notes you made. You worked so hard, and these notes will make people feel so happy and loved. You helped make the world a kinder place with your special writing!

parent_notes: Thank you notes combine multiple Montessori values: grace and courtesy (social awareness and gratitude), language (writing for a real purpose and real audience), and practical life (the process of writing, addressing, and mailing). The notes do not need to be long or perfect — authenticity matters more than spelling. Help the child think of specific things to be thankful for rather than generic thanks. 'Thank you for reading to me every night' is more meaningful than 'Thank you for being nice.' If the child writes to a grandparent or distant relative, actually mail the notes — receiving real mail is a powerful experience for the sender and recipient alike. This activity also models a lifelong practice of expressing gratitude.

title: Math Games Day — Addition and Subtraction Games
description: The child plays math games that reinforce addition and subtraction skills learned throughout the year. Games make review joyful and social while strengthening computational fluency.
instructions:
1. 'Today is Math Games Day! We are going to play games that use everything you learned in math.'
2. Game 1: Roll two dice, add the numbers. First to reach 50 wins. Use golden beads for tracking.
3. Game 2: Subtraction bowling — set up 10 objects, roll a ball, subtract how many fell.
4. Game 3: War with playing cards — each player flips two cards and adds them. Higher sum wins the round.
5. Play each game for about 8 minutes.
6. 'Math is fun! You use math every time you play a game.'
materials_needed: Golden beads or counters for tracking score
Paper and pencil for score keeping

slides.heading: Math Games Day
slides.mascot_explanation: Yay, it's Math Games Day! We get to play super fun games that use all the math you've been learning, like counting and adding. It's going to be so much fun, just like playing with your favorite toys!

slides.setup_instructions: Set up three game stations around the room. Have all materials ready for quick transitions between games.
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at all these cool things we need for our games! We have dice that have little dots to count, playing cards with numbers on them, and some things to knock over like bowling pins. We'll also use a ball and special counters to help us keep track, and paper to write our scores. Ask a grown-up to help you find these special game pieces!

slides.text: 'Today is MATH GAMES DAY! Did you know that every time you play a game with numbers, you are doing math? Let's play!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Today is super exciting because it's Math Games Day! Did you know that when we play games, we're actually doing math? It's true! We're going to play some amazing games that will help us practice our math skills.

slides.text: 'Game 1: Roll the Dice! Roll two dice and add the numbers together. Keep a running total. First one to 50 wins!'
slides.mascot_explanation: For our first game, we're going to roll these dice! See all the little dots? We count the dots on both dice and add them together to get a big number. We'll keep playing and adding until we reach the number 50!

slides.text: 'Game 2: Subtraction Bowling! We have 10 pins. Roll the ball, count how many fell. 10 minus [number that fell] equals how many are left?'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, let's play a bowling game! We set up 10 pins, and then you get to roll the ball and knock some down. We'll count how many pins fell over, and then we'll figure out how many are still standing by taking them away from the starting 10.

slides.text: 'Game 3: Addition War! We each flip two cards and add them. The bigger number wins the round!'
slides.mascot_explanation: This next game is called Addition War! We'll each get some cards, and we'll flip two cards at the same time. We add the numbers on our cards together, and whoever has the bigger number wins the round!

slides.prompt: Play all three math games! Keep score carefully. Which game was your favorite? Can you explain the math in each game?
slides.mascot_explanation: It's time to play all our awesome math games! We'll roll the dice, bowl some pins, and play Addition War, and we need to be super careful to keep track of our scores. Think about which game you like the best and why!

slides.text: 'Math games are the best! You used addition and subtraction in every single game. Math is everywhere — even in playtime!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child perform addition and subtraction fluently within the context of games, with accuracy and speed?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, we played so many fun math games today! You were so good at adding and subtracting numbers in every game. You showed me that math is everywhere, even when we're just having fun playing!

parent_notes: Games are a legitimate and valuable math activity — they provide repetitive practice in a context that feels like play rather than work. The child does dozens of addition or subtraction problems during a game without the fatigue of worksheets. Games also add social dimensions: taking turns, following rules, winning and losing gracefully. If the child struggles with mental addition during dice games, let them use their fingers or counters — the goal is enjoyment and practice, not testing. These games can continue all summer to maintain math skills. Consider making a 'Math Games Box' with dice, cards, and instructions that the child can pull out anytime. Mathematical fluency, like reading fluency, is built through joyful, frequent practice.

title: Around the World Review — My Favorite Continent
description: The child selects their favorite continent and creates a detailed poster showcasing what they learned about it. This review activity celebrates their geographic knowledge and honors their personal interests.
instructions:
1. 'We studied every continent this year! Which one is your favorite? Which one do you most want to visit?'
2. Child selects their favorite continent.
3. Provide a large poster paper. Child draws the continent shape and labels it.
4. Add: countries studied, animals, landmarks, foods, people, flags, fun facts.
5. Include at least one drawing and one written sentence for each fact.
6. 'If you could visit any place on this continent, where would you go? Why?'
7. Present the poster to the family.
materials_needed: Glue and scissors (for adding photos or cutouts)

slides.heading: My Favorite Continent
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at this! It says "My Favorite Continent," and that means we get to think about all the amazing places we learned about. We're going to pick the one you liked the most!

slides.setup_instructions: Set up a large workspace. Have continent reference materials accessible.
slides.mascot_explanation: Ooh, we need lots of fun things for our project! We have a big piece of paper called poster paper, and colorful markers and pencils to draw with. We also have maps and a puzzle map to help us remember what our favorite continent looks like. Can you ask a grown-up to help you find all these special things?

slides.text: 'We explored every continent this year — North America, South America, Europe, Africa, Asia, Australia, and Antarctica! Which one was YOUR favorite?'
slides.mascot_explanation: We learned about so many cool places this year, like North America, Africa, and even way down south to Antarctica! Now it's time to pick just one that you really, really liked, or maybe one you dream about visiting someday. Which continent is your super-duper favorite?

slides.text: 'Draw the shape of your continent big in the center of the poster. Use the puzzle map to help you get the shape right.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, let's draw the shape of your favorite continent right in the middle of your big paper! Use the puzzle map like a guide to make it look just right. You can do it!

slides.text: 'Now fill it with everything you remember! Countries, animals, landmarks, foods, flags. Write facts and draw pictures.'
slides.mascot_explanation: This is where we show off everything we know! Let's fill up the poster with all the cool things we learned, like the countries, the funny animals, tall buildings, yummy foods, and even the flags. We'll draw pictures and write down some fun facts too!

slides.text: 'If you could visit one place on this continent, where would you go? Draw yourself there! Write why you want to visit.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Imagine you could go anywhere on this continent – where would it be? Let's draw a picture of you visiting that special spot and write a little bit about why you want to go there. It's like planning your dream trip!

slides.prompt: Create a detailed poster about your favorite continent. Include at least 5 facts with drawings. Show where you would most like to visit!
slides.mascot_explanation: We're going to make a super poster today about your favorite continent! You'll draw pictures and write down at least five cool facts you remember, and don't forget to show where you'd love to visit. You have lots of time to make it amazing!

slides.text: 'Your poster is wonderful! You know so much about [continent name]. Maybe one day you really WILL visit all these places!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child create a detailed poster with accurate geographic, cultural, and biological facts about their chosen continent?
slides.mascot_explanation: Yay! Look at your beautiful poster! You are so smart and remembered so many wonderful things about [continent name]. I bet you'll visit all those amazing places someday!

parent_notes: Letting the child choose their favorite continent honors the Montessori principle of following the child's interest. Their choice reveals what captured their imagination — it might be the animals of Africa, the food of Asia, or the landscapes of South America. The poster-making process reviews all geographic knowledge from the year while developing artistic and organizational skills. Use this as an opportunity to notice gaps: if the child cannot remember much about a continent, that is useful information for summer learning. The 'where would you visit' question makes geography personal and aspirational. Consider displaying the poster during the celebration feast. This kind of personally meaningful review is far more effective than testing or quizzing.

title: Read-Aloud: Last Stop on Market Street by Matt de la Pena
description: A beautiful story about a boy and his grandmother who ride the bus to a soup kitchen, finding beauty and gratitude in everyday moments. This book celebrates community, generosity, and seeing the extraordinary in the ordinary.
instructions:
1. 'This book is about a boy named CJ and his Nana. They ride the bus every Sunday and CJ learns something important.'
2. Read with warmth. Give Nana a warm, wise voice.
3. When CJ complains ('How come we don't got a car?'), pause: 'CJ is comparing. Have you ever wished you had something someone else has?'
4. Each time Nana reframes CJ's complaint, highlight her wisdom: 'What did Nana help CJ see?'
5. At the soup kitchen ending: 'CJ felt glad to be there. Why do you think he felt that way?'
6. Discuss: 'Nana helped CJ see beauty everywhere. What beauty can YOU find in ordinary things?'
materials_needed: Last Stop on Market Street by Matt de la Pena

slides.heading: Read-Aloud
slides.mascot_explanation: Look! Today we're going to read a special story called "Last Stop on Market Street." It's going to be a super fun adventure together!

items: Last Stop on Market Street by Matt de la Pena
slides.setup_instructions: Create a comfortable reading space. This is a gentle, meaningful story that deserves a calm atmosphere.
slides.mascot_explanation: To get ready for our story, we need to find the book! It has a picture of a bus on the front. Let's snuggle up somewhere cozy so we can hear every word.

slides.text: 'This book is about a boy named CJ who rides the bus with his Nana every Sunday. He is going to learn something very special about seeing the world.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Our story is about a little boy named CJ and his Nana. They ride on a big bus every Sunday, and CJ is going to learn something really important about seeing things in a new way.

slides.text: Read the story. When CJ wishes for things: 'CJ wants a car, an iPod, a nicer neighborhood. Do you ever wish for things like that?'
slides.mascot_explanation: As we read, CJ might wish for things, like maybe a car or a cool toy. Sometimes, when we see others have something nice, we might wish for it too, right? We'll pay attention to what CJ wishes for.

slides.text: When Nana reframes: 'Every time CJ complains, Nana helps him see something beautiful. What did she point out?'
slides.mascot_explanation: Nana is very wise, and when CJ says he wants something different, she helps him see the good things around them. We'll listen carefully to what Nana shows CJ and think about how she helps him change his mind.

slides.prompt: Think about an ordinary part of YOUR day — riding in the car, eating dinner, walking outside. What beautiful things can you find if you look closely?
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, let's think about our own day. Maybe we ride in a car, or eat yummy food, or play outside. What special, beautiful things can we find if we look super close, just like Nana taught CJ?

slides.text: 'CJ learned that beauty is everywhere if you look for it, and that helping others makes us feel glad. What a wonderful lesson from Nana!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child identify Nana's perspective shifts and apply the concept of finding beauty in ordinary moments to their own life?
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, CJ learned such a good lesson today! He learned that we can find beauty everywhere and that helping people feels really, really good. You did a great job listening and thinking about it all!

parent_notes: Last Stop on Market Street is a Newbery Medal winner that embodies Montessori values: gratitude, community service, respect for all people, and mindfulness. Nana's technique — reframing complaints into moments of wonder — is a powerful parenting tool. The book also gently introduces economic diversity and service. The soup kitchen ending shows CJ learning that giving feels better than receiving. This connects to the Montessori grace and courtesy curriculum and the broader peace education philosophy. After reading, try Nana's technique in daily life: when the child complains, help them reframe. 'I don't like waiting' becomes 'What interesting things can you notice while we wait?' This shift in perspective is a life skill.

title: Sensorial Walk — Observing the World with All Five Senses
description: The child takes a mindful nature walk using all five senses — a celebration of the sensory awareness they have developed throughout the year. They record observations in a final nature journal entry.
instructions:
1. 'Your senses have become so sharp this year! Let's go on a special walk and USE all five senses.'
2. Before leaving: review the five senses. 'What do we see with? Hear with? Smell with? Taste with? Touch with?'
3. Walk slowly through the neighborhood or garden.
4. At each stop, focus on one sense: 'Close your eyes. What do you HEAR right now? Count the different sounds.'
5. Touch different textures: bark, leaves, stone, soil. Name the qualities.
6. Smell flowers, earth, air. 'How does summer smell different from winter?'
7. Return home and make a nature journal entry with all five senses documented.

slides.heading: Sensorial Walk
slides.mascot_explanation: Look! It says "Sensorial Walk" and "Observing with All Five Senses." That means we're going to go outside and use our eyes, ears, nose, hands, and mouth to discover all the wonderful things in nature!

slides.setup_instructions: Pack a small bag with journal, pencils, and collection bag. Plan a route through a garden, park, or nature area.
slides.mascot_explanation: We need a few special things for our walk today! We have a journal to draw in, pencils and crayons to make our pictures colorful, a bag to collect little treasures, and a magnifying glass to see tiny things up close. Ask a grown-up to help you get these ready!

slides.text: 'Today we are going on a SENSORIAL WALK! We will use every single sense: seeing, hearing, smelling, touching, and even tasting (safely!). Your senses are so much sharper than at the beginning of the year!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, we're going on a super special walk today, a "Sensorial Walk"! This means we're going to use ALL our senses – seeing, hearing, smelling, touching, and even tasting yummy things carefully. You've gotten so good at using your senses this year!

slides.text: 'First stop: SIGHT. Look around carefully. What colors do you see? How many shades of green? Any tiny creatures? Look closely!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, let's practice using our EYES! Look all around you, super carefully. Can you see all the different colors, like bright green leaves or a fuzzy brown bug? Let's try to find as many things as we can with our eyes!

slides.text: 'Now: HEARING. Close your eyes and be very quiet for one full minute. How many different sounds can you count?'
slides.mascot_explanation: Next, let's use our EARS! Close your eyes and be very, very still. Listen carefully to all the sounds around us. Can you hear the birds singing, or maybe the wind blowing? Let's count how many different sounds we hear!

slides.text: 'TOUCH: Feel this tree bark, this leaf, this stone. Describe each one with exact words — rough, smooth, bumpy, cool, warm.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Time to use our HANDS! Let's touch different things like the rough bark on a tree, a soft, smooth leaf, or a cool, hard stone. Tell me what each thing feels like – is it bumpy, prickly, or squishy?

slides.prompt: Make a nature journal page with five sections — one for each sense. Draw and write what you observed with each sense on our walk.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we get to make our nature journal! We'll make a special page for each sense. You can draw a picture of what you saw, what you heard, what you touched, and what you smelled. Tell me all the amazing things you discovered!

slides.text: 'You noticed so many things! Your senses are like superpowers — they help you understand the world in amazing detail. Keep using them this summer!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child make detailed observations using all five senses and use precise descriptive vocabulary?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did such a great job on our sensorial walk! You used your super senses to notice so many cool things in nature. It's like you have superpowers that help you see, hear, smell, touch, and taste all the wonders around us!

parent_notes: This sensorial walk is the culmination of the entire sensorial curriculum. At the beginning of the year, the child might have said 'I see a tree.' Now they should be able to say 'I see a maple tree with dark green leaves that are starting to turn at the edges, and the bark has deep grooves with tiny lichens growing in them.' This specificity is the gift of sensorial training. Walk slowly — much more slowly than you might naturally. Pausing to listen with eyes closed for a full minute is a meditation practice that develops both sensory acuity and mindfulness. The nature journal entry documents this refined perception permanently. Compare it to early-year nature observations to see the tremendous growth in vocabulary and detail.

title: Favorite Books of the Year — Reading Review and Recommendations
description: The child reviews all the books read and read-aloud throughout the year, selects their favorites, and writes short book recommendations for each. This celebrates their reading journey and practices persuasive writing.
instructions:
1. Gather the reading log or list of all books from the year.
2. 'Look at all the books we read together! Which ones were your very favorites?'
3. Child selects their top 5 favorites.
4. For each, write a recommendation: title, author, one sentence about the story, and why they liked it.
5. 'A recommendation helps other people decide what to read. Tell them why THIS book is great!'
6. Compile into a 'Recommended by [name]' booklet or poster.
7. 'Maybe someone will read a book because of YOUR recommendation!'
materials_needed: Reading log or list of year's books
The actual favorite books if available

slides.heading: My Book Recommendations
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at this! It says "My Book Recommendations," and that means we get to talk about all the super fun stories we read this year and pick our very favorites!

slides.setup_instructions: Compile the year's reading list. If possible, gather the actual books for the child to hold and browse.
slides.mascot_explanation: To make our recommendations, we need a few special things. We have a list of all the books we read, and we'll need some paper and a pencil to write. If you have the books themselves, that's even better so we can remember them!

slides.text: 'We have read SO many books this year! Let's look at the list. Do you remember all of these? Which ones were your very favorites?'
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's look at our reading list together! We've read so many books, can you believe it? Which ones were your absolute favorites, the ones that made you giggle or feel excited?

slides.text: 'Pick your top 5 — the books you loved THE MOST. The ones you would tell a friend to read.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, let's pick out just five of your most favoritest books! Think about the stories that you really, really loved and want to tell everyone about.

slides.text: 'For each one, write: the title, who wrote it, what it is about (just one sentence!), and why you loved it. That is a RECOMMENDATION.'
slides.mascot_explanation: For each of your favorite books, we're going to write down what it's called, who wrote it, just one little sentence about what happens, and why you liked it so much. This is called a recommendation!

slides.text: 'Draw a little picture for each book to make your recommendations look inviting. Someone might pick up a book because of YOUR review!'
slides.mascot_explanation: To make our recommendations extra special, we can draw a little picture for each book. This will help other kids see how much fun the book is and want to read it too!

slides.prompt: Write recommendations for your 5 favorite books. For each one: title, author, what it is about, and why you loved it. Add a drawing!
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, now it's time to do it! Let's write down all the important things for your five favorite books and draw a picture for each one. You can do it!

slides.text: 'You are a book critic! Your recommendations will help other kids find great books. You have read and enjoyed so many wonderful stories this year.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child write clear book recommendations that include title, author, summary, and personal opinion?
slides.mascot_explanation: Yay! You did it! You are like a book expert now, sharing your favorite stories with everyone. It's so cool that you read so many amazing books this year!

parent_notes: Book recommendations are a sophisticated form of writing — they require summarizing (comprehension), evaluating (critical thinking), and persuading (audience awareness). The child must think about what makes a book worth reading and articulate that for someone else. This is also a beautiful review of the year's literacy journey. Looking at the reading log, you will likely be impressed by the sheer volume and variety. If the child cannot remember a book, briefly summarize it — memory will often flood back. The recommendation list can be shared with friends, gifted to the librarian, or posted at home. It also serves as a starting point for summer reading: revisiting favorites is a wonderful summer activity.

title: Teach a Family Member — Sharing Math Knowledge
description: The child selects one math concept and teaches it to a family member (sibling, parent, grandparent). Teaching solidifies understanding and builds the child's confidence as a mathematician.
instructions:
1. 'Today YOU are the math teacher! Pick one math thing you want to teach someone.'
2. Help the child choose: counting with beads, addition, skip counting, fractions, or another favorite.
3. Plan the lesson: 'What will you show first? Then what? How will you know they understand?'
4. Child prepares materials.
5. Invite the 'student' (sibling, other parent, grandparent — in person or video call).
6. Child teaches the lesson, demonstrating with materials.
7. The 'student' asks genuine questions. Child answers.
8. Celebrate: 'You are an amazing teacher!'
materials_needed: A family member to be the 'student'
Optional: whiteboard for the child to write on

slides.heading: Math Teacher for a Day
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at this! It says "Math Teacher for a Day"! That means today, YOU get to be the super smart teacher and show someone all the cool math things you know. Isn't that exciting? We're going to have so much fun!

slides.setup_instructions: Let the child choose their material and set up their teaching area. Help arrange a time for the family member student.
slides.mascot_explanation: Here are the things we need for our special teacher day! We need the math game or toys you love the most, a cozy spot on the floor to sit, and your family member who is going to be your special student. Let's pick your favorite math thing and then go find your grown-up to help you get everything ready!

slides.text: 'Today YOU are the teacher! You get to teach someone in our family something amazing about math. What do you want to teach?'
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, this is the first big step! Today, YOU are the boss of the math lesson. You get to choose something super interesting about numbers or shapes to teach to someone in your family. What math magic do you want to share with them today?

slides.text: 'Let's plan your lesson. What will you show first? What will you explain? Think about what someone needs to know FIRST before they can understand.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we get to plan our super fun lesson! Let's think about what you will show them first. Maybe you'll show them your cool counting blocks, and then you can tell them how to count them. We want to make it easy for them to learn!

slides.text: 'Set up your materials. Practice what you will say. When your student arrives, welcome them and begin!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Time to get ready for your student! Let's put all your math toys in a nice pile, and you can practice telling them what to do. When your family member comes, you can say "Hello!" and start your amazing math lesson. You're going to do great!

slides.text: 'Great teaching! You explained that so clearly. Ask your student: Do you have any questions? Then see if they can try it themselves.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Yay, you did such a good job teaching! Now it's time to ask your student if they have any questions about what you showed them. Then, let's see if they can try doing the math thing all by themselves – that shows they learned it from you!

slides.prompt: Teach your math lesson to your family member student. Show the materials, explain how they work, let them try, and answer their questions!
slides.mascot_explanation: This is the best part! You get to teach your family member all about math. Show them your toys, tell them how it works, and let them try it too. They might ask you some questions, and you are so smart, you can answer them!

slides.text: 'You were a wonderful teacher! If you can teach something to someone else, it means you REALLY understand it. You are a true mathematician.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child teach a math concept clearly enough that the student can demonstrate understanding?
slides.mascot_explanation: You were the most amazing math teacher ever! Because you can teach someone else, it means you know math super, super well. You are a real mathematician, just like the grown-ups! High five!

parent_notes: Teaching is the highest form of learning. When a child must organize their knowledge, sequence it logically, and present it clearly enough for someone else to understand, they deepen their own comprehension dramatically. The 'student' should ask genuine questions — not trick questions, but honest ones like 'Why does that work?' or 'What happens if I put 11 units together?' The child's ability to answer these questions reveals the depth of their understanding. If a grandparent or other family member can be the student, this creates a beautiful intergenerational learning moment. Video call works well for distant relatives. The key is that the 'student' must be genuinely attentive and curious — this validates the child's knowledge and expertise.

title: My Experiment — Results and Conclusions
description: The child analyzes the results of their experiment from last week, compares results to their hypothesis, and draws conclusions. They complete the full scientific method cycle independently.
instructions:
1. 'Let's look at your experiment results! What happened?'
2. Review the data recorded in the science journal.
3. 'Was your hypothesis correct? Did what you predicted actually happen?'
4. If yes: 'Your prediction was right! What helped you make such a good guess?'
5. If no: 'That is GREAT! Scientists learn the most when results surprise them. What did you learn instead?'
6. Write the conclusion: 'I learned that ___ because ___.'
7. Draw a final diagram of the results.
8. 'You completed the ENTIRE scientific method by yourself!'
materials_needed: The experiment itself (for final observations if needed)

slides.heading: My Experiment
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at this! This is the title of our special science time where we get to be super detectives and figure out what happened in our experiment. We’re going to see what we learned!

slides.setup_instructions: Open the science journal to the experiment pages. If the experiment is ongoing, make final observations first.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, let's get our science tools ready! We have our special notebook, a pencil for writing, and some colorful pencils to make our drawings super pretty. These are all the things we used for our experiment, so let's find them all together.

slides.text: 'It is time to see what your experiment told us! Let's look at your observations and data. What happened?'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, let's peek inside our science notebook and see what happened! We're going to look at all the notes and pictures we made when we did our experiment to see what we discovered.

slides.text: 'Now let's compare: your hypothesis was [read it]. Was it correct? Did what you predicted actually happen?'
slides.mascot_explanation: Remember when we made a guess about what would happen? Now, let's look at that guess and see if it was right! Did our experiment do just what we thought it would?

slides.text: 'Write your CONCLUSION. This is what you learned. Start with: I learned that ___ because my experiment showed ___.
slides.mascot_explanation: It's time to write down what we learned! We'll say "I learned that..." and then tell everyone what our experiment showed us. This is like telling the story of our discovery!

slides.text: 'Draw a final picture showing your results. Label everything clearly — a scientist's drawings help others understand too.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Let's draw a picture of what our experiment showed us at the very end. We need to draw it very clearly so that everyone can understand what we found out, just like real scientists do!

slides.prompt: Complete your experiment write-up: compare results to hypothesis, write your conclusion, and draw a final results diagram. You did the whole scientific method!
slides.mascot_explanation: This is the super fun part where we finish writing everything down and draw our final picture. We are doing the whole science job, from asking a question to finding out the answer! You can do this!

slides.text: 'You asked a question, made a hypothesis, tested it, observed, and drew a conclusion. That is EXACTLY what real scientists do. You are a scientist!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child compare results to hypothesis, draw a logical conclusion, and articulate what they learned?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did it! You asked a question, made a smart guess, did an experiment, looked closely, and figured out what you learned. You are a real scientist, and that is so, so cool!

parent_notes: Completing the full scientific method cycle — from question through conclusion — is a major cognitive achievement for a young child. The most important moment is when results do not match the hypothesis. If the child is disappointed, reframe powerfully: 'Scientists are EXCITED when their hypothesis is wrong because that means they learned something new!' This resilience in the face of unexpected results is a life skill that extends far beyond science. Help the child write a clear conclusion using the sentence frame: 'I learned that ___ because ___.' This structure teaches them to connect evidence to claims, which is foundational for all future academic writing. Display the completed experiment alongside their portfolio.

title: Art Gallery — Curating a Personal Exhibition
description: The child selects their best artwork from the year and creates a mini art gallery with labels, descriptions, and a gallery guide. This celebrates their artistic growth and teaches curation.
instructions:
1. 'Artists have exhibitions in galleries! Today you are curating YOUR gallery.'
2. Gather all art from the year. Child selects 8-10 favorite pieces.
3. For each piece, write a gallery label: title, date, medium (paint, crayon, collage).
4. Add a brief artist's statement: 'I made this because ___' or 'This shows ___.'
5. Arrange art on a wall or display surface at child's eye level.
6. Create a gallery guide (a numbered list matching the art).
7. 'Welcome to the [child's name] Gallery! Give us a tour!'
materials_needed: All saved artwork from the year

slides.heading: Art Gallery
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at this! It says "Art Gallery" and "My Personal Exhibition." That means we are going to make a special place to show off all the super cool art you made this year!

slides.setup_instructions: Clear a wall or display area. Gather all saved art. Have index cards and tape ready.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at all these things we need for our art show! We have all your amazing artwork from this year, some little cards to write on, sticky stuff to hang things up, a pencil, and paper for our special guide. Ask a grown-up to help you find everything so we can get started!

slides.text: 'Real artists show their work in GALLERIES — places where people come to look at art. Today you are making YOUR gallery!'
slides.mascot_explanation: This part tells us that big artists have places called galleries where people come to see their paintings and drawings. Today, guess what? You get to be the artist and make your very own special gallery for *your* art!

slides.text: 'Choose your best art from the whole year. Look at all of it — which pieces make you feel proud?'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's time to pick your most favorite pictures and paintings from all the ones you made this year. Think about the ones that make you feel super happy or really proud when you look at them!

slides.text: 'Each piece needs a label, just like in a real museum. Write the title, when you made it, and what materials you used.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Every picture needs a little sign, like a name tag! We'll write down what your picture is called, what day you made it, and what cool stuff you used, like crayons or paint.

slides.text: 'Now hang your art on the wall! Put it at YOUR eye level so visitors can see it well. Space them out like a real gallery.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, let's put your amazing art on the wall! We'll hang it up so it's just the right height for you to see, and spread them out so everyone can see each special picture.

slides.prompt: Select, label, and hang your art. Write a gallery guide that tells visitors about each piece. Then give a tour of YOUR gallery!
slides.mascot_explanation: This is the fun part! We get to put up all your art, write the little signs, and make a map for people to follow. Then, you get to be the tour guide and show everyone all the wonderful things you made!

slides.text: 'Your gallery is beautiful! Each piece shows something you learned and something you felt. Art tells the story of who you are.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child curate a coherent exhibition, write descriptive labels, and articulate their artistic choices?
slides.mascot_explanation: Your gallery looks so amazing! Every single picture tells a story about what you learned and how you felt when you made it, and that's what makes your art so special and beautiful.

parent_notes: Creating a gallery transforms art from something hung on the refrigerator to something curated and valued. The child learns that their creative expression matters enough to be displayed formally. The gallery labels teach descriptive writing in a practical context. The artist's statement ('I made this because...') builds metacognitive awareness about creative choices. Keep the gallery up through the celebration feast so all family guests can enjoy it. Take a photo of the child standing proudly next to their gallery — this image captures the confidence that comes from seeing your work displayed with respect. This gallery can remain up all summer as a reminder of the year's accomplishments.

title: Year-End Celebration — Shopping and Preparation
description: The child goes shopping using their list and begins preparing food for the celebration meal. They practice real-world skills: navigating a store, finding items, making purchases, and following recipes.
instructions:
1. Review the shopping list from Day 1.
2. At the store: child helps find each item. 'What section would butter be in? Dairy!'
3. Child crosses items off the list as they go into the cart.
4. At checkout: child helps place items on the belt and counts money (if paying cash).
5. At home: begin preparing items that can be made ahead.
6. Child follows recipe steps with supervision.
7. Prepare table decorations: place cards, the decorated menu, flowers from the garden.
8. 'Tomorrow is the big celebration!'

slides.heading: Celebration Preparation
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at this! It says "Celebration Preparation" and "Shopping and Cooking." That means we're going to have a super fun party, and we need to get everything ready! We're going to shop for yummy food and then cook it all up.

slides.setup_instructions: Bring the shopping list and bags to the store. At home, set up the kitchen for cooking and the table for decorating.
slides.mascot_explanation: Oh, look at all these things we need for our party! We have our shopping list, a pencil to check things off, bags to carry our food, recipes for cooking, and things to decorate the table. Let's ask a grown-up to help us get all these ready to go shopping and get cooking!

slides.text: 'Time to shop for our celebration feast! You made the list — now let's find everything. What do we need first?'
slides.mascot_explanation: Yay, it's time to go shopping for our big celebration feast! Remember that list we made? We're going to be super shoppers and find every single thing on it. What do you think we need to find first?

slides.text: 'Cross each item off the list as we find it. You are doing the real shopping! What section should we look in for [item]?'
slides.mascot_explanation: We're doing such a great job finding everything! Every time we put something in our cart, we get to cross it off our list. Now, for the [item], what part of the store do you think we should look in? You're such a good helper!

slides.text: 'Now let's start cooking! What can we make ahead of time? Follow the recipe step by step.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we're home and it's time to be chefs! We get to cook some yummy food for our party. Let's look at our recipes and follow the steps very carefully, like a real chef. We can make some things now that will be ready later!

slides.text: 'While the food is cooking, let's decorate the table! Place your beautiful menu in the center. Make place cards for each guest.'
slides.mascot_explanation: While some food is cooking, we get to make our table look super special! We'll put our pretty menu right in the middle. Then, we'll make special cards for everyone who is coming to our party.

slides.prompt: Help cook one dish from the menu and decorate the celebration table. Make it beautiful and welcoming for your guests!
slides.mascot_explanation: This is the best part – we get to help cook our food and make the table look amazing for our guests! You are doing such a wonderful job making everything beautiful and welcoming. You've got this!

slides.text: 'The food is started, the table is decorated, and everything is coming together! You planned this whole celebration. Tomorrow will be wonderful!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child navigate shopping with a list, follow a recipe, and prepare a table setting?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did it! The food is cooking, the table looks so pretty, and our celebration is almost ready. You helped plan and make everything happen! Tomorrow is going to be so much fun because of all your hard work!

parent_notes: This lesson is deeply practical and deeply Montessori — the child is doing real work that contributes to the family in a meaningful way. At the grocery store, let them lead as much as possible: finding items, comparing prices, selecting produce. This is applied math, reading, and decision-making. In the kitchen, review safety rules but give maximum independence. The child has been cooking all year; trust their skills. The table decoration brings art and hospitality together. The entire process — from planning through shopping through cooking through decorating — is an executive function workout of the highest order. This is what Montessori means by 'preparation for life.'

title: Year in Review — Favorite Passages and Poetry Recitation
description: The child selects favorite passages from books read this year and practices reciting them along with any poems memorized. This celebrates the beauty of language and the child's growing literacy.
instructions:
1. 'This year we read so many wonderful words! Let's revisit the most beautiful ones.'
2. Browse through favorite books and find beloved passages.
3. Child selects 2-3 short passages to read aloud.
4. Practice reading with expression: 'Make your voice match the feeling of the words.'
5. Review any poems memorized during the year.
6. Practice reciting one or two poems from memory.
7. Plan a mini 'Poetry and Readings' performance for the celebration.
8. Create a simple program listing what will be recited.

slides.heading: Favorite Words
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at this! It says "Favorite Words" and talks about "Passages and Poetry." That means we get to remember all the super special words and stories we read together this whole year! It's like picking out the best treasures from our reading adventures.

slides.setup_instructions: Gather the year's favorite books and any poems the child has learned. Set up a reading corner.
slides.mascot_explanation: For our special word party, we need a few things. See? We need our favorite books from this year, and any poems we learned. We also need some paper and a pencil to make a little list of what we'll share. Can you help ask a grown-up to find these things for us?

slides.text: 'Words can be so beautiful! This year we read amazing stories and poems. Let's find our favorite words to share.'
slides.mascot_explanation: This says, "Words can be so beautiful! This year we read amazing stories and poems. Let's find our favorite words to share." Isn't that exciting? We get to pick out the words that made us feel happy or surprised or like we were on an adventure!

slides.text: 'Look through our books. Which part is your VERY favorite? The part that gives you a special feeling? Let's mark those pages.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, let's look through our books together. Remember all the fun stories we read? Think about which part made you giggle, or made you feel brave, or made you wonder. Let's put a little marker on those pages so we know they are your super special favorites!

slides.text: 'Now practice reading those parts out loud. Use your best reading voice — slow, clear, and full of feeling!'
slides.mascot_explanation: It's time to practice reading our favorite parts! When we read, we want to use our best reading voice. That means saying the words nice and slow, making them sound clear, and putting all the feelings into them, just like the characters in the story!

slides.text: 'Do you remember any poems by heart? Let's practice! Stand up straight, speak clearly, and let the words come from your memory.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Do you remember any poems we learned? Poems are like songs with words! Let's stand up tall and try to say them from our memory. We want to speak them clearly so everyone can hear how wonderful they sound!

slides.prompt: Practice reading your favorite passages and reciting poems. Make a program listing what you will perform at the celebration!
slides.mascot_explanation: We're going to have a little performance! We'll practice reading our favorite parts and saying our poems. Then, we'll make a special list, like a program, to show everyone what beautiful words we picked to share. You're going to be amazing!

slides.text: 'You are going to give a beautiful performance! The words you chose show what moved your heart this year. That is the magic of reading.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child read passages with expression and recite at least one poem from memory?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did such a wonderful job picking out your favorite words and practicing them! Those words you chose really show what was special to you this year, and that's the real magic of reading and sharing stories. You are such a fantastic reader!

parent_notes: Oral recitation is an ancient and powerful educational practice. When a child reads a beloved passage aloud with expression, they are integrating decoding, comprehension, fluency, and emotional intelligence. The poems they have memorized are now part of them — they will carry these words for life. Do not worry if the recitation is not perfect; what matters is the child's relationship with language. Their choice of favorite passages reveals what resonated emotionally. A child who chooses the tender moment from a story feels deeply. A child who chooses the funny part appreciates humor in language. Both are beautiful. The mini performance at the celebration gives this practice a purpose and audience, which motivates careful preparation.

title: Math in Real Life — Celebration Cooking Math
description: The child applies math skills to the celebration meal preparation: measuring ingredients, doubling a recipe, setting the table with correct place settings, and calculating time for cooking.
instructions:
1. 'Today we use math for our celebration feast! Math is everywhere in cooking.'
2. Measuring: 'The recipe says 2 cups of flour. Let's measure carefully.'
3. If doubling: 'We need to make MORE because we have extra guests. If the recipe says 1 cup, and we need DOUBLE, how much is that?'
4. Table setting: 'How many people are coming? How many plates do we need? Forks? Glasses?'
5. Time: 'The cake bakes for 30 minutes. If we put it in at 3:00, when do we take it out?'
6. Fractions: cutting a pie or cake into equal pieces.
7. 'You used math for everything today!'

slides.heading: Celebration Math
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at our special title slide! It says "Celebration Math" and "Math in the Kitchen." That means we get to use our super smart math brains to help make yummy food for a party!

slides.setup_instructions: Set up the kitchen for cooking. Have the recipe visible. Prepare table setting items for counting.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at all these fun things we need for our cooking adventure! We have a recipe card with instructions, special cups and spoons to measure with, a clock to tell time, pretty plates and forks for our table, and paper and a pencil to write things down. Ask your grown-up to help you find all these exciting tools so we can start cooking!

slides.text: 'Math is not just for math time — you use it ALL the time! Today we will find the math hiding in our celebration cooking.'
slides.mascot_explanation: Guess what? Math isn't just for when we sit at our desks! We use math all the time, even when we're cooking yummy treats for a celebration. Today, we're going to be kitchen detectives and find all the math hiding in our cooking fun!

slides.text: 'The recipe says we need 1 and a half cups of sugar. Show me 1 and a half cups. What does the half look like in the measuring cup?'
slides.mascot_explanation: This recipe needs some sugar, and it says we need one whole cup and then another little bit, like a half cup! Can you help me see what one whole cup looks like, and then what that half cup looks like in our measuring cup? We need to be super careful measurers!

slides.text: 'We have [number] guests coming. How many plates do we need? How many forks? Cups? Count them out!'
slides.mascot_explanation: We have some special friends coming to our party! We need to count how many plates, forks, and cups we need so everyone has their own special spot at the table. Let's count together and make sure everyone gets exactly what they need!

slides.text: 'The food cooks for 25 minutes. It is [time] now. What time should we take it out? Let's figure it out on the clock!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Our yummy food needs to cook for a little while, and our clock tells us when it's ready. If it's this time now, and it needs to cook for 25 minutes, can you help me figure out what time it will be when it's all done? We'll use our clock to be super time detectives!

slides.prompt: Help measure all the ingredients, set the table for the right number of people, and calculate cooking times. Math is the secret ingredient!
slides.mascot_explanation: Yay, it's time for our big cooking activity! We get to be amazing chefs and use our math to measure everything, count all the plates and forks for our guests, and figure out exactly when our food will be ready. Math is like our secret ingredient to make everything perfect for our celebration!

slides.text: 'You used measuring, counting, fractions, and time today — all for real cooking! Math is not just in books. It is part of everything we do!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child accurately measure ingredients, count table settings for guests, and calculate cooking times?
slides.mascot_explanation: You did such an amazing job using math today for our celebration feast! You measured like a pro, counted all the table settings perfectly, and figured out all the cooking times. Math really is the best secret ingredient for making yummy food!

parent_notes: Applied math in cooking is one of the most authentic ways to demonstrate that math matters. Every measurement, every count, every time calculation is real math with real consequences (too much salt ruins the dish!). This lesson makes the abstract concrete in the most delicious way possible. The doubling challenge is particularly powerful: if the child can figure out that double 1/2 cup is 1 cup, they are demonstrating fraction operations in a practical context. Telling time forward (the cake needs 30 minutes, it is 3:00, so we take it out at 3:30) is applied addition with time units. Let the child do as much of the measuring and counting as possible — accuracy matters here, and they will rise to the challenge because the stakes (a successful meal) are real.

title: Peace and Kindness — Reflecting on Grace and Courtesy
description: The child reflects on the grace and courtesy lessons from the year: greetings, table manners, conflict resolution, kind words, and respect for others. They create a 'Kindness Pledge' for the summer.
instructions:
1. 'All year we practiced being kind, respectful, and gracious. Let's remember what we learned.'
2. Review key grace and courtesy lessons: greeting people, saying please and thank you, handling disagreements, being a good host, listening carefully.
3. 'Which of these are you really good at now? Which ones are you still working on?'
4. Role-play: practice a few scenarios (meeting someone new, handling a disagreement, welcoming a guest).
5. Write a 'Summer Kindness Pledge': 3-5 things the child commits to practicing.
6. Decorate and sign the pledge.
7. Post it somewhere visible at home.

slides.heading: Peace and Kindness
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at this colorful slide! It says "Peace and Kindness" and "Grace and Courtesy Review." This means we're going to think about all the super nice ways we learned to be with our friends and family all year long.

slides.setup_instructions: Prepare a special piece of paper for the kindness pledge. Have a calm, reflective space ready.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at these special things we need for our activity! We have some pretty paper to make our promise on, and a pencil and colorful crayons to make it look beautiful. Ask a grown-up to help you find these so we can make something special together!

slides.text: 'One of the most important things we learned this year is how to be kind, respectful, and gracious. Let's remember together.'
slides.mascot_explanation: This is like a special reminder from our teacher. It says that all year, we've been learning to be kind and nice to everyone. We're going to think about all the good things we did and remember how important it is to be good friends.

slides.text: 'How do we greet someone? How do we say thank you? What do we do when we disagree with someone? Let's practice!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now we get to think about all the ways we learned to be polite and helpful! We'll remember how to say "hello" nicely, how to say "please" and "thank you," and even how to share when we disagree. We'll practice being super good friends!

slides.text: 'You have become so good at these things! Now let's make a KINDNESS PLEDGE for the summer — promises about how you want to treat others.'
slides.mascot_explanation: You've learned SO much this year about being kind and thoughtful! Now, we're going to make a special "Kindness Pledge" for the summer. It's like a promise to yourself about how you want to keep being a wonderful, kind person when school is out.

slides.text: 'Write your pledge: I promise to... Think of 3 to 5 things that matter to you. Then sign your name at the bottom!'
slides.mascot_explanation: This is where we make our promise! We'll write down 3 to 5 things we promise to do to be kind this summer, like sharing toys or giving hugs. Then, we'll sign our name at the bottom to make it official, just like grown-ups do!

slides.prompt: Write and decorate your Summer Kindness Pledge. Choose 3-5 promises about how you will be kind and respectful. Sign it like a real pledge!
slides.mascot_explanation: It's time to make our Kindness Pledge super special! We'll write down our promises and then decorate our paper with the colorful crayons to make it look amazing. Signing our name at the end makes it our very own promise for the whole summer.

slides.text: 'Your kindness pledge shows what kind of person you are choosing to be. Being kind is a choice we make every day, and you have practiced it all year.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child articulate specific grace and courtesy behaviors and commit to continuing them?
slides.mascot_explanation: Look at your beautiful Kindness Pledge! You worked so hard, and it shows how much you care about being kind and respectful. You've learned so many wonderful ways to be a good friend, and your pledge will help you remember to keep being that amazing person all summer long!

parent_notes: Grace and courtesy is uniquely Montessori — it treats social skills with the same respect and explicit instruction as academic subjects. By the end of the year, these behaviors should be largely habitual, but naming them explicitly in this review helps the child recognize their own growth. The Kindness Pledge is a powerful tool because it represents the child's own values, not rules imposed from outside. When a child writes 'I promise to use kind words even when I am angry,' they are articulating a personal commitment to emotional regulation. Post the pledge somewhere visible and refer to it gently throughout the summer. This is Montessori's peace education in action: the child is choosing to be a peaceful person, not being told to behave.

title: Read-Aloud: The Giving Tree by Shel Silverstein
description: A timeless story about generosity, love, and the changing relationship between a boy and a tree. This read-aloud invites deep conversation about gratitude, giving, and growing up.
instructions:
1. 'This is a story about a tree and a boy who grow up together. Listen carefully to how their friendship changes.'
2. Read slowly and thoughtfully — this book has natural pauses.
3. As the boy keeps taking: 'How do you think the tree feels? Why does the tree keep giving?'
4. At the ending (the stump and the old man): 'What do you think this story means?'
5. Connect to the child's own experience: 'Who in YOUR life gives like the tree? How can you be sure to give back?'
6. 'This year, your parents/teachers have been like the tree — giving and giving to help you grow. And you gave back by working hard and learning!'
materials_needed: The Giving Tree by Shel Silverstein

slides.heading: Read-Aloud
slides.mascot_explanation: Look! We're going to read a super special story called "The Giving Tree." It's a book that many people love, and we're going to read it together right now!

items: The Giving Tree by Shel Silverstein
slides.setup_instructions: Create a quiet, intimate reading space. This book invites deep reflection.
slides.mascot_explanation: This is the book we'll be reading, "The Giving Tree." Find a cozy spot with a grown-up, and get ready to hear a wonderful story about a tree and a boy.

slides.text: 'This is a very special story. It has been loved for a long, long time. It is about a tree and a boy, and how they love each other.'
slides.mascot_explanation: This is the start of our story! It's all about a special tree and a boy who are friends, and how they love each other very much as they grow up together.

slides.text: Read slowly. Let the pauses breathe. When the boy takes the apples: 'Is the tree happy? Why?'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, we're going to read the story super slowly, like we're tiptoeing. When the boy takes the apples from the tree, I want you to think: Is the tree happy when it gives the apples? Why do you think so?

slides.text: As the boy keeps taking more: 'What do you notice about what the boy does each time he comes back? How do you think the tree feels?'
slides.mascot_explanation: Keep listening closely! As the boy comes back and takes more things, think about what he's doing. How do you think the tree is feeling when the boy keeps taking?

slides.prompt: Think about who in your life is like the giving tree. Draw a picture of that person (or people) and write one thing you want to give THEM.
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it's your turn to be a super-duper artist! Think about someone who is like the giving tree and gives lots of love, like your mommy or daddy. Draw a picture of them and think of one special thing you want to give back to them.

slides.text: 'The tree gave everything because of love. The people who help us learn and grow do the same thing. How can we show them we are grateful?'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child reflect on themes of generosity and gratitude and identify giving relationships in their own life?
slides.mascot_explanation: The tree loved the boy so much, it gave him everything! Just like the tree, the people who help us learn and grow love us too. How can we show them we are thankful for their love?

parent_notes: The Giving Tree is a book that different children interpret differently, and all interpretations are valid. Some see unconditional love; others see selfishness; still others see the natural cycle of dependence and independence. Do not push a particular interpretation — let the child think and feel their own way through it. For a child ending kindergarten, the natural connection is to the adults who have given to help them grow. But also notice if the child identifies with the tree — some children are natural givers and need to see themselves reflected in that role. The poignancy of this book at year's end is powerful: the child IS growing up, becoming more independent, and beginning to give back. Acknowledge that transition with tenderness.

title: Sound Exploration — Musical Instruments and Pitch
description: The child demonstrates their refined auditory discrimination by identifying instruments by sound, ordering Montessori bells by pitch, and creating a simple musical composition as a capstone sensorial activity.
instructions:
1. 'Your ears have learned so much this year! Let's celebrate your sense of hearing.'
2. If you have Montessori bells: child grades them from lowest to highest pitch.
3. If not: use glasses filled with different water levels and strike with a spoon.
4. Blindfold listening: play recordings of different instruments. Child identifies each.
5. 'Can you hear the difference between a violin and a flute? A drum and a piano?'
6. Create a simple melody: child arranges 4-5 pitches in an order they like and plays their composition.
7. 'You composed music with your trained ear!'
materials_needed: Montessori bells or water glasses and spoon
Paper and pencil for notating the composition

slides.heading: Sound Exploration
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at this! We're going to play a super fun game with sounds today. We'll learn all about how some sounds are low, like a big bear growling, and some are high, like a tiny mouse squeaking!

slides.setup_instructions: Set up bells or fill 5-7 glasses with different water levels. Queue instrument recordings.
slides.mascot_explanation: Okay, let's get our special listening tools ready! We have either these pretty bells that make different sounds, or we can use glasses with water in them – the water makes the sound change! We'll also need a blindfold to help us listen extra carefully, and some paper and a pencil for later. Ask a grown-up to help you find these things!

slides.text: 'Your ears are amazing! This year you learned to hear differences in pitch, rhythm, and tone. Let's put those skills to the test!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Your ears are like superheroes! You've learned so much about listening to music and sounds. Now, we're going to use those amazing listening skills to play a special game and hear all the different sounds.

slides.text: 'First, put these sounds in order from lowest to highest. Listen carefully to each one and find its place.'
slides.mascot_explanation: It's time to listen to some sounds and put them in order! We have some special bells or water sounds, and we need to listen very carefully to find the lowest sound and put it first, then the next lowest, all the way to the highest sound. You can do it!

slides.text: 'Now close your eyes and listen. I will play recordings of different instruments. Can you name each one just by its sound?'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, let's try something super tricky and fun! Close your eyes tight, and I'll play a sound from a musical instrument, like a drum or a piano. Your job is to listen very, very carefully and guess which instrument is making that sound!

slides.text: 'Last challenge: CREATE your own music! Pick 4 or 5 pitches and arrange them in an order that sounds beautiful to you. Play it for me!'
slides.mascot_explanation: This is your chance to be a real musician! We're going to pick four or five different sounds, like little musical notes, and you get to put them together in any order you like to make your very own song. Then, you can play your special song for me!

slides.prompt: Grade the pitches from low to high, identify instruments by ear, then compose your own short melody! Play it several times until it sounds just right.
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, you did it all! You listened to the sounds and put them in order, you guessed the instruments just by hearing them, and you even made your own music! Your ears are so smart and can do amazing things.

slides.text: 'You ordered pitches, identified instruments, and even composed music! Your ears can do incredible things. Keep listening closely to the world around you.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child grade pitches accurately, identify at least 4 instruments by sound, and create an intentional melody?
slides.mascot_explanation: You are such a fantastic listener! You ordered the sounds, you guessed all the instruments, and you even made up your own song – that's so cool! Keep listening to all the wonderful sounds in the world around you.

parent_notes: Auditory discrimination is the most overlooked sensorial skill in many curricula, but Montessori prioritizes it because it underpins language development (distinguishing phonemes), music appreciation, and environmental awareness. The water glass activity is a wonderful substitute if you do not have Montessori bells — fill glasses with varying amounts of water and strike with a metal spoon. The child should be able to order 5-7 pitches from low to high. Instrument identification by sound demonstrates sophisticated auditory processing. The composition activity is magical: the child arranges sounds deliberately, making aesthetic choices. This is artistic expression through the auditory sense. Simple notation (drawing circles at different heights) can represent the melody visually.

title: Letter to Next Year's Self — Looking Forward
description: The child writes a letter to themselves to be opened at the start of next school year. They describe what they accomplished, what they are proud of, and what they hope to learn in elementary.
instructions:
1. 'Let's write a special letter — to YOURSELF! You will open it on the first day of school next year.'
2. Help the child brainstorm what to include: accomplishments, favorite memories, advice for future self, hopes and goals.
3. Write the letter: 'Dear Future Me, This year I learned ___. I am proud of ___. Next year I hope to ___. Love, Me.'
4. Fold the letter and seal it in an envelope.
5. Write on the envelope: 'TO: [name] — OPEN ON THE FIRST DAY OF SCHOOL!'
6. Store in a safe place.
7. 'When you open this next year, you will remember everything about kindergarten!'

slides.heading: Letter to Future Me
slides.mascot_explanation: Wow, look at this! We're going to write a super special letter to YOU, but the YOU that will be in school next year! It's like sending a message to your future self.

slides.setup_instructions: Set up a special writing space. Have the envelope ready for sealing.
slides.mascot_explanation: To write our special letter, we need a few things! We need paper to write on, a pencil to draw with, and an envelope to keep our letter safe. We also have pretty stickers and colorful pencils to make it extra special! Ask a grown-up to help you find them.

slides.text: 'Today you are writing a letter to someone very special — YOURSELF! But the you from NEXT YEAR. You will open it on the first day of school!'
slides.mascot_explanation: Today, we're going to write a secret letter just for you! It's like a time capsule for your own brain. You'll open it when you come back to school next year, on the very first day!

slides.text: 'Tell your future self what you learned this year. What are you most proud of? What was your favorite part of kindergarten?'
slides.mascot_explanation: Think about all the amazing things you did in kindergarten this year! What did you learn? What makes you feel super proud of yourself? What was your very favorite thing to do? Tell your future self all about it!

slides.text: 'Now write about what you hope for next year. What do you want to learn? What are you excited about? Any advice for yourself?'
slides.mascot_explanation: Now, let's think about next year! What do you hope to learn when you go to your new school? What fun things are you excited to do? Maybe you can even give your future self some good advice!

slides.text: 'Fold your letter, put it in the envelope, and seal it. Write on the front: DO NOT OPEN UNTIL THE FIRST DAY OF SCHOOL!'
slides.mascot_explanation: When your letter is all done, we’ll fold it up nice and neat and put it inside the envelope. Then, we’ll write on the outside, "Do Not Open Until The First Day Of School!" so your future self knows when to peek.

slides.prompt: Write your letter to future you. Include: what you learned, what you are proud of, what you hope for, and any advice. Seal it in the envelope!
slides.mascot_explanation: Now it’s your turn to write! Think about all the fun things you learned and did, and what you hope for next year. Then, put it all in the envelope and seal it up tight! You can do this!

slides.text: 'Your future self is going to LOVE reading this letter! You will be amazed at how much you remember and how much you have changed. What a wonderful gift to yourself!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child write a reflective letter that includes accomplishments, pride, and future goals?
slides.mascot_explanation: Yay! You did it! Your future self is going to be so happy to get this letter and remember all the cool stuff you did. It's like a special present from you to you!

parent_notes: This letter serves as both a reflection exercise and a time capsule. When opened at the start of the next school year, it will powerfully remind the child (and you) of where they were at this moment. The letter also creates a sense of continuity — the child's educational journey is not ending, just transitioning. Encourage specific details rather than generalities: 'I learned to read chapter books' rather than 'I learned a lot.' If the child is anxious about the transition to elementary, this letter can include self-reassurance: 'Dear Future Me, remember that you were nervous about kindergarten too, and it turned out great!' Store the sealed envelope somewhere you will find it in September. The act of sealing it creates delicious anticipation.

title: Math Scavenger Hunt — Finding Math Everywhere
